metadata.title: Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD)
synonyms: pervasive developmental disorder not otherwise specified
anatomical location body part affected: Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is a disorder thought to affect the brain and central nervous system that ultimately affects the entire individual
description: ASD encompasses a continuum of neurodevelopmental disorders that are characterized by impairment in social skills and communication, along with stereotyped repetitive behavior(90,91)

ASD is the term that is now being used for the diagnoses that, in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fourth Edition (DSM-IV ) and International Statistical Classification of Diseases and Related Health Problems  (ICD-10),  were included under the term pervasive developmental disorder (PDD). According to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition (DSM-5 ), which was published in 2013, ASD encompasses the following diagnoses that were previously classified as PDD:(57) –Autism –Asperger syndrome (or Asperger’s disorder) –Pervasive developmental disorder–not  otherwise specified (PDD-NOS) –Childhood disintegrative disorder
The elimination of autism, Asperger syndrome, PDD-NOS,  and childhood disintegrative disorder as separate entities is due to the inconsistent distinction between them(57)

In an Australian study of 210 individuals who met DSM-IV  criteria for autistic disorder, only 57.1% met DSM-5  criteria for ASD diagnosis. High-functioning  individuals were less likely to meet the DSM-5  criteria for ASD, with the most common reason for exclusion being a failure to satisfy all three criteria in the social-communication domain(81)
Most studies suggest that 50–75%  of patients in whom ASD was diagnosed according to the DSM-IV  criteria continue to meet criteria under the DSM-5   (105)
In the United States, current estimates are that 1/88 children,(2) including 1/54 boys, has ASD(90)
The worldwide prevalence is about 1%(92) –Prevalence is reported to be increasing at an estimated rate of 10-17%  annually(57)
ASD is commonly diagnosed around age 4; however, parental unease regarding a child’s behavior generally begins around 12-18  months of age(3)

ICD-9 codes.299.00: infantile autism, current or active state

ICD-10 codes.F84.4: overactive disorder associated with mental retardation and stereotyped movements
ICD-10 codes.F84.9: pervasive developmental disorder, unspecified (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference and not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: Reimbursement for physical therapy for ASD has been a subject in recent lawsuits and settlements with insurance companies. For example, according to a 2012 settlement, an insurer was required to provide medically necessary physical, occupational, and speech therapy to members denied treatment since January 2009, and to reimburse those who paid for the services themselves. The insurer had claimed it provides coverage for physical, occupational, and speech therapy to address health needs, but not for educational and social purposes. Some of the cases involved therapies for patients with ASD

Ten U.S. states provide Medicaid Home and Community-Based  Services (HCBS) waiver programs for children who have ASD and are Medicaid eligible. This federally supported program allows states to provide community-based  services to assist individuals with developmental disabilities to live in their community. Each state determines the amount of financial support and type of benefits(79) –Massachusetts is the first state to require participation for families of young children with ASD seeking Medicaid HCBS waiver services. Under the Children’s Autism Waiver Program, selected low-income  families receive intensive, in-home autism interventions and supports used to supplement special education services available from the school system. Families are provided substantial financial support to select the providers and services(79)
presentation signs and symptoms: Early signs/symptoms(3) –Impaired social communication (e.g., does not respond to name being called) –Impaired play or adaptive skills (e.g., does not imitate others’ actions) –Impaired language and cognition (e.g., little to no babbling) –Regression (e.g., loss of functional skills) –Impaired visual skills (e.g., impaired tracking) –Impaired motor skills (e.g., delayed acquisition of walking) –Impaired sensory integration –Altered eating and sleep habits –Impaired affective expression (e.g., lack of social smiling, eye contact, nonsocial smiling)(84)

General signs/symptoms –The extent of symptoms can vary tremendously. There will be some level of impact on social abilities and response to environment –Perseverating behaviors and inflexible routines are characteristic of ASD(5) –Delay in acquisition of developmental motor milestones(1,4)

Specific signs/symptoms –Social manifestations -Little to no eye contact(6) -Persons are regarded in the same manner as objects(6)  -Lack of interest in shared activities(90) -Lack of peer interaction(6) -Instability of mood (e.g., out-of-place laughter)(93) -Appear as if they are “in their own world”(6) -Inability to read the expressions/faces of others or pick up on social cues(6,7) -Some children may hug, make eye contact, or even smile, but this interaction is only periodically observed(8) -Inability to empathize(9) –Communication manifestations -Lack of social-emotional  reciprocity: the tendency of a patient to engage the attention of another person to share enjoyment of objects or events(8) -The patient may communicate only to ask for something (e.g., point to a card depicting lunch selections), not to illustrate or explain something(6) -Inflexibility(90) -Echolalia (repetition of a word or phrase spoken by another person)(6) -Limitations or delays in expressive and receptive language(6) -Inability to partake in pretend play(6) -Hyperlexia or premature decoding ability with little understanding of text(6) -Referring to self in the third person(6) -Reversing of pronouns(6) -Impaired comprehension of irony or sarcasm(5) –Behavior/sensory manifestations -Sensory integration issues; may have a decreased perception of pain or an increased sensitivity to light touch, for example(5) -Perseverates(6) -Lining up of objects(9) -Preoccupation with components of items(8) -Enjoyment in watching objects spin(6) -Intense reactions to change -Flapping of hands(10) -Biting(9) -Head-banging(9) -Insomnia(11) -Intense tantrums –Motor manifestations -Decreased coordination(4,10,12) -Gait deviations(4,10) -Walking on toes(6) -Atypical posturing(10) -May present with mild hypotonia(5) -Delays or deficits in development of motor or physical activity behaviors(58) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors

causes: Generally accepted that there is an atypical pattern of brain maturation in children with ASD(10)

Genetics may play a role in the etiology of ASD, although this has yet to be established–In the case of identical twins, if one twin has ASD the risk of the other twin being affected by ASD is 36-95%.(2) Innonidentical twins, the risk is 0-31%(2)–For parents who have one child with ASD, the risk in subsequent children is 2-18%(2)

Gestational factors that could affect neurodevelopment, such as complications during pregnancy and exposure tochemicals(92)–Immunological incompatibility (i.e., maternal antibodies directed at fetus) may contribute(93)
Delivery by caesarian section has been found to be associated with a modest increase in the likelihood of ASD(106)
pathogenesis: Largely unknown, although most current theories focus on the disruption of normal cerebral development–Because it seems likely that ASD’s neurodevelopmental defect is not a single anomaly, its study occurs in severaldomains (e.g., genetic, immunopathogenic, neurofunctional)

Physiological findings–Studies have found that the head circumference of children with ASD generally has an atypically rapid rate of increasebetween 6 and 14 months(8)–Toddlers with autism appear to have a larger brain volume with noted enlargement of the cerebellum, amygdala, andcerebrum compared to toddlers without autism(8)–Clinical signs of ASD correlate with abnormal brain development. Research shows there is overgrowth and neuraldysfunction at young ages that involves an abnormal excess neurons in the prefrontal cortex. This abnormalneurobiological development has been reported to begin at 9 to 18 months of age(90)–There is increasing evidence of alterations in both grey matter and white matter structure(91)–Neurophysiological indicators of auditory and visual processing, such as EEG recordings, show a relationship betweenseverity of autism symptoms and impairment of auditory processing(99)
risk factors: Males are 3–4 times more likely than females to have ASD(1)

Having a sibling with ASD(3)–There is a 5% risk of siblings developing ASD; however, if fragile X syndrome is present, the sibling risk increases to50%(90)–There is a 70% to 95% concordance rate for ASD in monozygotic twins and a 5% concordance rate in dizygotic twins(90)

Certain prenatal and perinatal complications, including maternal gestational bleeding, gestational diabetes, umbilical cordcomplications, birth trauma, low birth weight, low 5-minute  Apgar score, ABO blood group or Rh factor incompatibility,hyperbilirubinemia,(93) and caesarean section(106)
Genetic factors(60)–The heritability index is reported to be 0.82 to 0.90(90)

Certain genetic and chromosomal abnormalities(2)–De novo mutations account for 15% to 20% of ASD cases(90)–Chromosomal abnormalities in 6 major genes have been identified, with as many as 20–30  additional genes, especiallythe glutamate-related  genes, playing contributing roles(90)–About 10% of children with ASD are also identified as having Down syndrome, fragile X syndrome, tuberous sclerosis,or other genetic or chromosomal disorders(2)
Maternal diabetes(80)–There is a significant association between maternal diabetes and increased risk of ASD in the offspring based on a 2014systematic review and meta-analysis  of the literature(80)
factors not associated with an increased: No correlation between increased prevalence of ASD and use of measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine–No association between ASD and MMR vaccine; based on systematic review of 12 articles(14)–No association between ASD and MMR vaccination in retrospective study of 537,303 children(15)–No association between MMR vaccine and PDDs in case-control study involving 1,294 cases and 4,469 controls; 78% vs.82% had MMR vaccination before diagnosis (or matched age)(16)–No association between MMR vaccine and ASD in community-based case-control  study involving 98 cases and 142controls(17)

No association between thimerosal-containing  vaccines and ASD–No association between ASD and thimerosal-containing  vaccines in systematic review of 10 epidemiological studies;studies suggesting association were poor quality, and results could not be interpreted; two pharmacokinetic studies foundthat ethyl mercury has a short half-life,  making association improbable(18)–No association between ASD and thimerosal-containing  vaccines in cohort of 467,450 children(19)–No consistent association between thimerosal-containing vaccines and any adverse neurodevelopmental outcome inretrospective study of 140,887 children in three HMOs(20)–No association between thimerosal-containing  vaccines in infants and developmental disorders in prospective UnitedKingdom cohort of > 14,000 children(21)–No association between thimerosal-containing  vaccines in infants and developmental disorders in retrospective U.S.cohort of 109,863 children(22)–Early thimerosal exposure NOT associated with neuropsychological deficits at ages 7–10  years(23)

However, a 2011 study reported a positive association between ASD prevalence and childhood vaccination uptake acrossthe United States, suggesting that further study into the relationship between vaccines and ASD is warranted(61)
Infection in the first 2 years of life not found to be associated with ASD(24)

No association found between ASD and defined gastrointestinal disorders (i.e., celiac disease, necrotizing enterocolitis,chronic diarrhea, malabsorption, food intolerance, recurrent gastrointestinal symptoms)(25)
No association between maternal smoking and ASD(107)

overall contraindications precautions: Training New clinicians may require training/instruction on the emotional needs of the parents Clinicians should include the family/caregivers in the treatment sessions, explain and demonstrate therapeutic strategies, and provide oral and written instruction as indicated
No contraindications specific to ASD are listed in the literature reviewed

Precautions should be taken when treating patients with ASD due to potential for wandering behavior self-injurious  behavior poor safety awareness poor impulse control rigid adherence to routines communication deficits

If patient has a coexisting seizure disorder, seizure precautions apply General guidelines(26) –Eliminate dangerous objects from area –Stay with the patient –Do not hold down extremities –Release restrictive clothing –Follow aspiration precautions (i.e., rotate head to side, assess airway, wait for tonic-clonic  activity to pass before administering artificial respiration if indicated)

Comorbid diseases associated with ASD could predispose to fracture risk(100) Low bone mineral density has been reported in peripubertal boys with ASD  In a study conducted in the United States, researchers found a higher odds ratio for hip fractures in children and young adults with ASD (3–22  years) and in older adults with ASD (23–50  years) than in persons without ASD, as well as a higher odds ratio for forearm and spine fractures in women aged 23–50  with ASD(100) –Rate of fractures was investigated using a national database of emergency room visits

course of treatment.medications: Medications for current illness/injury Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken as prescribed? There is no standard medication for treatment of ASD Medicines that are sometimes used to treat behaviors related to ASD include selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) and antipsychotic medicines A 2013 Cochrane review of the literature on the use of SSRIs for patients with ASD found no evidence of an effect of SSRIs in children and emerging evidence of harm. There is limited evidence of the effectiveness of SSRIs in adults with ASD from small studies in which risk of bias is unclear(73) A 2012 systematic review of the literature on medication treatments for patients with ASD aged 1330  years found insufficient strength of evidence for all outcomes associated with medications tested in this population(62) Eight medication studies were identified; only four were determined to be of fair quality Main outcomes were the effects on core symptoms of ASD and comorbid symptoms and conditions, including sleep disorders, anxiety, hyperactivity, and challenging behavior (e.g., irritability, agitation) Most medications prescribed are for the comorbid conditions associated with ASD(8) The FDA has approved risperidone (ages 516 years) and aripiprazole (ages 617  years) for the treatment of irritability in ASD(8)
diagnostic tests completed: Currently there are no definitive tests to confirm the diagnosis of ASD(6)
According to the DSM-5,  for ASD to be diagnosed a patient must present with the following characteristics:(57,63)
Persistent deficits in social communication and social interaction across multiple contexts as manifested by the following:
Deficits in communicative behaviors used for social interaction
Deficits in developing, maintaining, and understanding relationships
Restricted repetitive patterns of behavior, interests, or activities as manifested by at least two of the following, currently or historically:
Stereotyped or repetitive motor movements, use of objects, or speech
Insistence on sameness, inflexible adherence to routines, or ritualized patterns
Hyper-  or hyporeactivity to sensory input or unusual interest in sensory aspects of environment
Symptoms originating in early childhood but may not be fully manifest until social demands exceed capacity (e.g.,
during middleschool  years, later adolescence, or young adulthood). This is a change to the DSM-IV criterion for ASD that symptoms must be present by the age of 3 years
Diagnostic instruments have limitations. An individual’s diagnosis of ASD should never depend on the diagnostic classification of a single measure(64)

Typically a developmental pediatrician, pediatric psychiatrist, or psychologist confirms a diagnosis of ASD. During this process the patient may undergo a multidisciplinary evaluation that includes assessment by rehabilitation professionals and a social worker(27)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies or alternative therapies (e.g., diet modification) and whether or not they help Diet modification Eighty-three  percent of children with ASD received a range of dietary manipulations including the use of special diets such as a glutenfree,  casein-free  diet and dietary supplements (micronutrients, vitamins, minerals, and fish oils) based on a survey of 258 parents and 244 healthcare professionals in the United Kingdom. However, researchers concluded there is inadequate evidence to support dietary interventions(82) A systematic review reports insufficient evidence regarding gluten-  and casein-free diets(42) Based on a Cochrane review of 2 randomized trials, which met inclusion criteria, evaluating gluten-  and/or caseinfree  diets in 35 patients with an ASD. Meta-analysis  was not feasibleoverall autistic traits, social isolation, and overall ability to communicate and interact The other study found no significant differences in three outcomes when treatment and control were compared Unable to evaluate 10 outcomes due to skewed data Touch/massage therapy Qigong massage, delivered over 5 months, was reported to improve symptoms of ASD(28) Based on a quasi-randomized  controlled trial conducted in the United States involving 46 children with ASD Children were randomized (with some restrictions) to one of two groups20 training and treatment sessions over 5 months; daily massage administered by caregiver; children also received standard care Control  wait list; standard care Results  teachers and parents of the children in the intervention group reported significant improvements in

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: symptoms -A noncomparative United Kingdom study evaluating the efficacy of touch therapy for children with ASD and their parents reported subjective results, including the children having improved tolerance to touch, ADL simplification, parents sensing an increased “closeness” with their children, and children appearing more at ease with themselves(43) -Twelve parents and 12 children were included in the study -Eight weeks of 1-hour  sessions of instruction were provided -Music therapy may improve social and communication skills and behavior in children with ASD(44) -Authors of a 2015 systematic review based on 15 articles concluded that music therapy improved interpersonal skills, social skills, and cognitive skills in children with ASD(108) -For many alternative/complementary treatments, evidence does not support their use. Some treatments have greater potential risk either directly (e.g., side effects of compounds) or indirectly (e.g., by diverting financial or psychosocial resources)(94)Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpfulDocument strategies that are calming to the patient and situations that may induce unwanted behaviors. Document the use of a “sensory diet” (a personalized activity plan designed to provide sensory input throughout the day) prescribed by a healthcare professional
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms. See Presentation/signs & symptoms
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (AM, mid-day, PM, night); also document changes in symptoms due to other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night and any difficulty falling asleep; sleep disturbances are common in children with ASD(28) -Insomnia is estimated to occur in 4483%  of school-aged  children with ASD(93) -Are any pharmacological or behavioral interventions used to improve insomnia?
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician -Based on a 2014 systematic review, parents of children with ASD report their children having feeding difficulties, with the most common issues being restricted diet variety, food neophobia, food refusal, limiting diet based on texture, and a propensity toward being overweight(78) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe ________________________ (See assessment below)

past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask parent about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, psychiatric disorders, orthopedic disorders, etc. It is estimated that 25% of those with ASD have a comorbid seizure disorder and 75% also have developmental delay(90) Patients with ASD are at risk for developing comorbid psychiatric disorders, especially attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), anxiety, bipolar disorder, and depression. It is reported that one of these psychiatric disorders is diagnosed in 2029%  of patients (90)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including overthe-counter  drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask parent about other symptoms the patient may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Vocation/avocation and associated repetitive behaviors, if any -Is the patient involved in any recreational or leisure activities? -How much daily physical activity does the patient habitually perform? -Ritualistic and compulsive behaviors are common(93) -The activities and play of children with ASD may be more rigid, repetitive, and monotonous than those of other children(93) -Note any repetitive self-stimulatory  or self-injurious  behavior(93)
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Functional limitations/assistance with ADLs/adaptive equipment -What ADLs can the patient perform? -Any adaptive or assistive devices used at home?
social and occupational history.living environment: Inquire about stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives (siblings/caregivers/group home), etc. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary? How is the patient able to negotiate the school environment? Are community resources available and accessible? -Aspects of the family emotional climate have been related to long-term  outcomes of persons with ASD(101) -Results of a longitudinal study conducted in the United States suggest that greater improvements in ASD symptoms and maladaptive behaviors in adolescence and adulthood are associated with higher-quality mother-child relationships(101)

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting.)  Evaluation of the patient with ASD will vary depending on age, severity of symptoms, and the setting in which the patient is currently being evaluated. Standardized  assessments paired with clinical observations tend to be the most common methods of evaluation. The clinician should modify the examination as indicated and appropriate; the information listed below is meant to serve only as a guide
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Anthropometric characteristics –Measure height and weight and calculate body mass index (BMI) -High rates of overweight (BMI > 25) and obesity (BMI > 30) have been reported in children with ASD. In a sample of 376 children with ASD in the United States, 35.1% were overweight or obese(95) -Deficiencies in motor proficiency, leading to inactive behavior, have been implicated(65)(95) -Core symptoms of ASD may impact motivation to participate in structured physical activities with other children -Families and therapists may be more likely to use food as a reward in children with ASD due to lack of social motivation -Restrictive/repetitive behavior patterns often include selective eating. Children with ASD have been shown to have higher intakes of low-nutrition,  energy-dense  food -ASD comorbidities such as poor sleep quality and mood disorders may be a cause and a consequence of unhealthy weight
relevant tests and measures.balance: Evaluate balance reactions. Pediatric Balance Scale (PBS) can be used –Researchers in the United States who compared motor functioning among children with ASD, children with ADHD, and typically developing children found that tasks requiring the ability to maintain static balance were predictive of ASD when differentiating between ASD and ADHD(102) -The deficits in static balance probably reflect problems with integration of spatial and temporal information, and may be associated with abnormal gait in children with ASD
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: Monitor breathing to assist with determining fatigue and endurance levels
Observe overall endurance through general activities

The 6-minute  walk for distance test (6MWT) is an appropriate test of endurance for adults with ASD -Further research is needed to explore the ability of the 6MWT to measure significant and clinically important changes in chronic pediatric conditions.(66) Modified test procedures in the pediatric population may be required(66) •Functional mobility (including transfers, etc.)

Observe the patient during coordination tasks such as jumping jacks, cross marching, skipping, galloping, standing/ hopping on one foot, ability to participate in catching/throwing/kicking a ball, and whether all of these skills are similar to those of peers
Document the patient’s motor planning ability for novel tasks and whether visual demonstrations were required for participation in tasks
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Assess the patient’s gait; note any deviations(29) –Gait impairment may be evident with tandem gait, heel, or toe walking –Assess coordination with locomotor skills such as running and jumping as ableDocument presence of joint laxity or hypermobilityAssess both fine and gross motor ability. Many standardized neuromotor developmental tests (described below) include standardized tests of gross and fine motor skills  –Studies indicate that there is a significant difference in the gross motor skills of children with ASD and children without ASD(65) –Very young children with ASD have been found to have significant motor delays that become more pronounced with
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Arousal, attention, cognition (including memory, problem solving) –Assess patient’s ability to communicate and level of arousal –Document length of time the patient is able to attend to directions and activities and what strategies may work to assist with redirection to task as appropriate –Did strategies such as concise, clear directions, visual schedules, or movement breaks allow for an increase in attention or participation? –Document frustration tolerance and presence of impulsivity –Is the patient able to follow single-step  and multistep directions? –Document presence and level of eye contact –Document if the patient becomes overstimulated with movement tasks –Document the patient’s ability to transition between activities and response to redirection –Obtain results of neuropsychological testing completed by other disciplines where available

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Diagnosis/need for treatment Expert consensus supports that early intervention (birth to age 3 years) can make a dramatic impact on outcomes in a patient with ASD.(2) The patient may present with fine and gross motor skill delays along with the obvious global communication delays The multiple developmental and behavioral impairments associated with ASD require an interdisciplinary team of healthcare professionals who directly communicate with each other in the coordination of care and services provided to the patient and his or her caregivers Older children and adults with ASD can also benefit from exercise programs, which may be prescribed and/or supervised by a physical therapist
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Schizophrenia with childhood onset(93) Congenital deafness or hearing impairment(93) Selective mutism(8) Obsessive-compulsive  disorder(OCD)(8) Stereotypic movement disorder(8) Intellectual disability without ASD(93) Developmental language disorder(93) Psychosocial deprivation(93) Rett syndrome(93)
prognosis: ASD is a chronic, lifelong disorder;(2) however, a subset of patients do make improvements significant enough that they no longer meet diagnostic criteria for ASD(98) –Even in this optimal outcome group subtle language impairments may persist(98)

In a prospective study in the United Kingdom that involved 85 children in whom ASD was diagnosed at age 2 years and who were reassessed 17 years later, researchers found that 9% of participants had largely overcome core difficulties associated with ASD and no longer retained a diagnosis of ASD(76)  –Eighty-five  percent of subjects’ intellectual disabilities at age 19 years were predicted based on assessment at 2 years of age of verbal and nonverbal IQ scores

Using the U.S. National Longitudinal Transition Study-2  data collected on 1,100 high school students who received special education services in the autism category, 81% of students with ASD who went on to postsecondary education enrolled in a 2-year community college at some point in their postsecondary careers(75) –Students in the science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields were more likely to persist in a 2-year community college and were twice as likely to transfer from a 2-year  community college to a 4-year university than their peers in non-STEM  fields
Approximately 1/10 children affected will later develop Parkinson’s disease or catatonic traits(10)

With early diagnosis and proper treatment intervention and support, children without language and intellectual impairments have a fair to very good prognosis despite persistent ongoing symptoms. The development of oral communication skills and the cognitive and behavioral capacity for inclusion in a typical education setting with typically developing peers is associated with the best outcomes(90)

Individuals who lack joint attention by the age of 4 years, lack functional speech by the age of 5 years, or present with intellectual disability, seizures, comorbid medical or psychiatric syndromes, and a pervasive lack of social awareness have a poorer prognosis(90)

According to a large survey, a substantial number of children who had received a diagnosis of an ASD at one time were reported to no longer have the disorder(37) –Based on a cohort study conducted in the United States in 2007 –78,037 children aged 3–17  years were included; results were obtained through (parental) telephone survey –453 (32%) of 1,412 children who had at one point received a diagnosis of an ASD no longer had the condition at the time of the survey
Early motor delays may be predictive of future communication delays in children at risk for ASD(71)

In a United States retrospective study of 535 children with ASD, 70% of children attained phrase speech and 47% attained fluent speech at ≥ 4 years of age. Higher nonverbal IQ and less social impairment were both independently associated with the acquisition of phrase and fluent speech as well as an earlier age at speech acquisition(74)
Persons with ASD are reported to have a mortality risk 2.8 times higher than persons without ASD of the same age and sex(92) –Thought to reflect co-occurring  medical conditions
Little is known about aging with ASD(92) –There is generally a pattern of improvement in maladaptive behaviors and autistic symptoms with age in ASD(101)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Speech therapist Occupational therapist Physical therapist Developmental pediatrician Audiologist(3) Ophthalmologist(5) Resource specialist within the school system Dentist –Parents should attempt to locate a dentist with experience evaluating and treating children with special needs, in particular children with ASD. Most children are treated under general anesthesia or unnecessary sedation; however, dentists and dental hygienists can be educated about how to complete an oral assessment in children and adults with ASD to safely and effectively accommodate these patients(88) Social worker Child psychiatrist Clinical neuropsychologist –Authors of a United States study investigated how the families of children with ASD organized their day-to-day life and the emotional impact of raising a child with a severe disability. The authors reported that family members may rely on  inflexible routines to manage their days and have trouble including daily activities that are upbeat and have a positive value(38) –An association between parental emotional stress and unfulfilled social and psychological needs was reported in a study in which 26 families of adults with ASDs were interviewed(39) –Based on a study conducted in Spain, for both mothers and fathers of children with ASD the severity of the disorder and social support played significant roles in the family quality of life. The child’s behavior problems have a negative indirect effect on the family’s quality of life(86) –Parental stress, particularly on the mother as the primary, daily caregiver, is high in families of children with ASD -In a Canadian study of mothers of children with ASD, the discontinuity of services was a significant predictor of disrupted employment and/or leisure time for the mother. Occupational imbalance and professional sacrifice was related to mothers’ forgoing participation in personally meaningful occupations in order to focus time on navigating and participating in professional services for their child. Healthcare providers need to remember that family issues, in addition to direct services related to the child specifically, are just as important when promoting family-centered care(87) -Authors of a 2015 systematic review of the OT interventions for children with ASD and their parents designed to improve parental stress, self-efficacy,  coping, resilience and family participation in daily life concluded that studies of children with ASD do not routinely measure parental and family outcomes. The authors recommended that more studies examine these issues(109) V ocational therapy for adults with ASD
other considerations: Authors of a 2015 review, based on 456 studies, identified the following 27 focused intervention practices as having met the criteria for evidence-based  practice (EBP) in the treatment of ASD. (To be determined EBP, the practice must be supported by 2 high-quality  experimental design studies,5 high-quality  single-case design studies involving at least 20 subjects, OR a combination of 1 high-quality  experimental design study and 3 high-quality  single case design studies)(110) –Antecedent based intervention –Cognitive behavioral interventions –Differential reinforcement of alternative, incompatible, or other behavior –Discrete trial treatment –Exercise – as a means for reducing problem behaviors or increasing appropriate behavior –Extinction –Functional behavior assessment –Functional communication training –Modeling –Naturalistic intervention –Parent-implemented  intervention –Peer-mediated  instruction and intervention –Picture exchange communication system –Pivotal response training –Prompting –Reinforcement –Response interruption/redirection –Scripting –Self-management –Social narratives –Social skills training -Authors of a 2015 meta-analysis  concluded that children with ASD can benefit from social skill interventions implemented with peers in a school setting(111) -The effect size was moderate to strong and the quality ratings were generally in the acceptable to high range for this review of 37 studies –Structured play groups –Task analysis –Technology-aided  instruction and intervention –Time delay  –Video modeling –Visual supports

Behavior intervention –Applied behavioral interventions may not yield superior outcomes when compared to standard care alone for preschool children with ASDs; however, the authors concluded that more studies with larger sample sizes are warranted(40) -Based on a systematic review of small randomized or quasi-randomized  controlled trials -Meta-analysis  was conducted of four of the trials evaluating the effect of applied behavioral interventions on children aged 18 months to 6 years with an ASD –Comprehensive behavioral intervention may improve outcomes in children with ASDs(41) -Based on a small United States randomized trial involving 48 children aged 18-30  months with ASD or PDD-NOS -Participants were randomized to one of two interventions and were followed for 2 years -Early Start Denver Model (ESDM) intervention –20 hours/week from clinicians; 5 hours/week from parents; additional community intervention as desired by parents -Standard community intervention -Results -45/48 children were analyzed -ESDM was associated with significantly greater improvement in -cognition (measured via the Mullen Scales of Early Learning) -adaptive behavior (measured via the Vineland Adaptive Behavior Scales) -diagnostic status (shifting from autistic disorder to PDD-NOS)

Environmental modifications –A non-comparative  study conducted in the United Kingdom of eight children with ASD that evaluated the impact of a new playground design on peer interactions reported significantly increased social initiations and frequency of group play with the new plan(45) -The new playground had four main objectives -Provide a suitable amount of physical tests (e.g., a climbing wall, which placed a certain level of physical demand on the children in order to foster true physical work) -Provide backing for imaginary play (e.g., play items were straightforward and consistent with routine; the new playground utilized a train theme) -Provide prearranged flow to playground (e.g., playground was based on a course; the slide rounded to the next pursuit) -Provide observation sites (e.g., a lookout tower to watch and study other children without the pressure of peers too close by)
treatment summary: There is a significant need for more randomized controlled trials that evaluate the efficacy of various treatment interventions for individuals with ASD –In a 2014 Australian study, ~50% of the 235 occupational therapists who treated patients with ASD indicated that they lacked confidence at least some of the time in regard to assessment, intervention, and knowledge of ASD. Experience treating patients with ASD and continuing education were significant predictors of confidence(77)

Authors of a 2015 systematic review utilizing 66 articles about OT interventions to improve social participation, play, leisure, and restricted and repetitive behaviors in children with ASD found the following:(112) –Strong evidence exists for improvements in social participation utilizing social skills groups, the Picture Exchange Communication System, joint attention interventions, and parent-mediated  strategies –A few interventions show moderately strong evidence for improving play, leisure, and restricted and repetitive behaviors -Strongest support for improving leisure activities was strategies in the context of recess time at school and for Social Stories -Behavior techniques within OT, such as antecedent manipulation and self-management,  had moderate support for improving restricted and repetitive behaviors. Exercise still needs more clinical trials to determine its efficacy

The author of a 2015 systematic review came to the following conclusions about OT interventions to promote vocational skills, ADLs, iADLs, education, and sleep in patients with ASD:(113) –Mobile and tablet technologies supported for vocational skills. Some support for Cognitive Orientation to Occupational Performance, sensory integration, and contextual interventions in supporting occupational performance  –Yoga and brief exercise may improve classroom performance and behavior whereas group physical activities may assist school readiness variables –Support for feeding and eating interventions was limited –Studies investigating interventions for sleep were lacking

Successful treatment of children under 3 years of age involves parental participation, early intervention, increased intensity and duration of treatment, and individualized treatment(46) –Based on a systematic review of 32 controlled studies

Service delivery models/early intervention –A home-based  intervention program, in conjunction with a center-based  program, may further improve cognitive and behavioral development over a center-based  program alone(47) -Fifty-nine  children participated in the Australian study, 39 of whom had an ASD -The children were randomized to treatment and control groups -The treatment group had a special education teacher come to their homes for a total of 40 visits over 1 year in addition to the center-based  program -Cognitive and behavioral measures were significantly increased in the treatment group –Solid evidence is lacking in regard to various forms of early intervention in the treatment of ASD(48) -Authors of a systematic review reported no meticulously controlled studies found; only one study utilized randomization of those evaluated and a control group –Early intervention often focuses primarily on communication and behavioral concerns -A lack of focus on motor skills and physical activity has been identified(67) -Inclusion of gross motor programs into early intervention plans for children with ASD is highly recommended based on results of a study indicating that motor skills become progressively more delayed with age even when controlling for cognitive factors(67) –Further research into physical activity programs is needed to assist in identifying the influence of motor performance and physical activities on the physical development of children with ASD(65) -Authors of a 2016 study in Taiwan provide supporting evidence that physical activity can be an appropriate treatment intervention in order to improve motor skills and executive functioning(114) -Twenty-two  children were randomized to either group A (intervention group) or group B (control group) -The study was designed so that group A received the intervention during the first 12 weeks, while group B did not. After the initial 12 weeks, group B received the intervention while group A did not -Table tennis was the physical activity chosen. Each intervention lasted 70 minutes, twice weekly for 12 weeks (total of 24 sessions). Sessions were divided into warm up (5 minutes), motor skills tasks (20 minutes), motor skills training related to executive function (20 minutes), group games (20 minutes), and cool-down  (5 minutes) -Both groups demonstrated improved scores on the BOT-2  and Wisconsin Card Sorting Test. In addition, those in group A were able to sustain the effectiveness of physical activity for at least 12 weeks

Therapeutic exercise –Aerobic exercise may improve/correct academic responses, but not on-task  time or stereotypic behaviors, in children with ASD(49) -Based on a United States research study of 9 children ages 3–6 years -All children participated in the treatment condition and control condition -During the treatment phase, the children participated in 15 minutes of aerobic exercise followed by a classroom task -During the control phase, the children participated in a classroom task only –Exercise may temporarily decrease stereotypic behaviors in children with ASD(50) -Based on a systematic review -Review included 7 studies (of various designs and quality) with a total of 26 children with ASD -The included studies investigated the impact of exercise (e.g., jogging) on stereotypical behavior

Aquatic therapy –Aquatic physical therapy may improve swimming skills and quality of life in children with ASD(51,52) -Based on a research study of 11 children with ASD who participated in a 10-week  aquatic therapy program(51) -Based on a research study of 12 children with ASD who participated in either aquatic therapy or usual activity(52)

Functional training –A treadmill walking program for adolescents with ASD may reduce BMI and increase exercise capacity(53) -The study took place in Australia and the program was 9 months long -Ten subjects were assigned to the intervention group (treadmill walking) or control group (leisure activity) -Significant improvements in BMI and exercise capacity were noted in subjects who participated in treadmill training

Hippotherapy –Hippotherapy may lead to improvements in symptoms in children with ASD(54) -Based on a pilot, randomized controlled trial in the United States -Included 34 children with an ASD -Participants were randomized to one of two groups -Intervention – therapeutic horseback riding; 12 weeks; 1 hour/week -Control – waiting list for program -Results (results comparing the two groups) -The intervention group experienced significantly greater improvements in -sensory seeking -sensory profile -attention and distractibility -sensory sensitivity -activity level -social response scale -social motivation –Increased frequency of weekly hippotherapy improves aberrant behaviors associated with ASD(85) -Based on a U.S. single-subject  design study of 3 boys aged 6–8 years with ASD -Frequency at baseline was 1 time a week; treatment intervention increased to 3 and 5 times a week over a 4-week  period -Counts of target behaviors were based on the Aberrant Behavior Checklist–Community,  which assesses behaviors and measures intervention effects of individuals with ASD -Seventy percent of target behaviors improved during the intervention and 63% of the improved target behaviors persisted during the withdrawal phase of the study -Increased doses of hippotherapy were significant for magnitude of change, and the effect of these improvements was generalized within the child’s home and community

Sensory integration therapy –Authors of a 2015 systematic review found moderate evidence for the use of Ayres Sensory Integration for persons with ASD,whereas results for other sensory-based  methods were mixed(55) -Based on 23 reviewed articles . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program  Behavioral concerns Limit behavioral outbursts/coping strategies when they do occurBehavior modification _ Social Communication and Emotional Regulation and implementing Transactional Supports – The SCERTS Model(1) _ _ A comprehensive approach that assists in promoting emotional regulation and communication(1) _ _ An example of a strategy using this model would be the incorporation of breaks into the patient’s day allowing for modulated activity and sensory input(1) _ _ Applied behavioral analysis (ABA) can have a large role in behavior modification with a significant emphasis placed on rewarding positive behaviors in children with ASD(56)Progress each unique patient as indicated and appropriateImplement a home program based on specific needs of

desired outcomes and outcome measures: Increased receptive language/increased expressive language; increased overall communication–AOSI, CARS 2
Reduced behavioral outbursts/use of coping strategies when they do occur–SRS
Attainment of motor milestones/improve motor skills–BSID-III,  BOT-2,  EDP, PDMS-2,  PEDI
Increased physical activity–Children’s Assessment of Participation and Enjoyment/Preference for Activities of Children (CAPE/PAC), 6MWT
Implementation of a sensory diet/sensory strategies

maintenance or prevention: In April 2016, the Center for Autism & Neurodevelopmental Disorders announced it had received funding to study the link between exercise and anxiety reduction in children with autism. See http://www.thecenter4autism.org/Portals/0/Uploads/Documents/AIR-P%20Exercise%20Grant%20Press%20Release.pdf
Continue physical activity in the community to maintain fitness and maximize functional mobility
Most children will require some degree of assistance as adults with ASD(90)

Employment Some major companies such as Microsoft provide career opportunities for persons with disabilities; seehttps://www.microsoft.com/en-us/diversity/inside-microsoft/cross-disability/hiring.aspx

Several countries/continents have published their own clinical practice guidelines and policy statements regarding identification, evaluation, and treatment intervention for persons with ASD. These are publicly available online In the United States, these include –American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) –Cincinnati Children’s Hospital Medical Center –Autism Society of Greater Cleveland Autism Task Force –Ohio Developmental Disabilities Council Autism Task Force –American Academy of Neurology and Child Neurology Society –American Occupational Therapy Association  –American Academy of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry –California Department of Developmental Services –Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics In the United Kingdom, these include –National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence (NICE) –Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network (SIGN) In Asia, these include –Academy of Medicine Singapore/Ministry of Health In Australia and New Zealand, these include –New Zealand Ministry of Health

Very early intervention for infants at risk for ASD may be beneficial for infants and parents(103) Based on a 2015 systematic review that included 9 studies investigating interventions for infants under 24 months with or at risk for ASD Parent-mediated  programs for prevention and early intervention for infants at risk are feasible and may improve short-term outcomes, including social engagement and communication

Results of a preliminary study in the United States suggest that parent report of early emerging social communicative skills can help identify siblings of children with ASD who are at high risk, as early as 12 months(104) Decrease in the level of social engagement and play as well as limited motor, vocal, and action imitation skills are red flags among high-risk  siblings Patient Information
